Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Mass Spectrometer to Enable Research and Education at the Interface of Chemistry, Biology, and Materials Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) programs, Professor William Horne from the University of Pittsburgh and colleagues Tara Meyer and Alexander Deiters have acquired a matrix assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometer (MALDI-TOF/TOF MS). In general, mass spectrometry is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex matrices. A laser impinging on the inert matrix embedded with the sample, vaporizes and ionizes the sample. The ions pass into the mass spectrometer where the masses of the parent ion and its fragment ions are measured. In a time-of-flight instrument the ions are accelerated by an electric field to allow further characterization. MALDI TOF combines gentle ionization (ideal for producing intact ions of peptides, proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, synthetic polymers, and other similarly sized species) with a detection mode that offers an excellent balance between sensitivity and accuracy across a wide mass range. This highly sensitive technique allows identification and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the University and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse students in research and research training with this modern analytical technique.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) constructing structurally defined supramolecular biomaterials; (b) developing strategies for designing biostable mimics of complex protein folding patterns; (c) providing insights into the fundamental role of sequence in dictating polymer properties; (d) searching for approaches for small-molecule regulation of synthetic oligonucleotides in biological systems and (e) developing methods for site-specific protein mutagenesis that expand beyond the 20 canonical amino acids.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mass spectrometry (MS) is a central analytical tool in the chemical sciences and is particularly well suited to provide structural information about large, complex molecules. The purpose of this National Science Foundation Major Research Instrumentation grant was to fund the acquisition of a state-of-the art MS instrument as a new shared resource to support research, teaching, and outreach across the chemical, biological, and materials sciences at the University of Pittsburgh.

The instrument purchased with the support of this grant has had a positive impact on research at the University. Over the course of the project, utilization of the new MS system has contributed directly to research efforts of >90 students and 15 faculty in the Department of Chemistry, including members of groups underrepresented in the chemical sciences. The research enabled by measurements made on the instrument spans multiple fields, including polymer science, nanomaterials, chemical biology, and neuroscience. The fundamental scholarship involved in these various projects leads to potential broader impacts related to areas such as drug delivery, responsive materials, and biomedical diagnostics.

The newly acquired instrument has also had a positive impact on science education at the University. Experiments conducted on it have advanced the dissertation research of graduate students and helped to support the education of undergraduates. It has been made available for walk-on access by trained student users, giving these scientists-in-training valuable hands-on experience with advanced analytical instrumentation. Further, the MS instrument was incorporated into the curriculum of three courses during the project: one introductory undergraduate, one upper-level undergraduate, and one graduate.

Looking forward, the impact of the shared MS instrument acquired with the support of this grant is expected to endure, as it continues to be used to advance research and education within the University.
